page.title: 11MELSONBY-The Village School
page.content: The history of the village school begins in{1757}with{Wm. Cockin}who by a{Deed of Endowment}gave the{annual {income from the rent of land}to cover the costs of{a Master & rented room for{the instruction of 6 poor children of Melsonby Parish in{reading, writing {and the common rules of arithmetic. In{1863}the{National School}(later C.ofE. School) was rebuilt at the expense of the{Rector Rev. W. Ellison. This school remained in use until its closure in 1959 when the{pupils were {transferred to}the{Methodist School . The{Methodist School}was{built}in {1857}at a{cost}of approximately{Â£740. The school population as remained at about 40 for some years now in spite of the increase in size of the village (in 1890 there were 100 pupils at the Methodist School alone!). Children over 11 years now go to Richmond.
